Award.AwardTitle: Engaging and Retaining Low-Income and First-Generation Community College Students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving the retention and success of low-income and first-generation (LIFG) students, overwhelmingly enrolled in community colleges, is critical for increasing the number of STEM graduates nationwide. Red Rocks Community College, Lakewood, Colorado in partnership with the Colorado School of Mines will develop new approaches and models that better engage and support LIFG students in pre-engineering programs in order to provide deeper and more integrated learning experiences. This will lead to improved success, retention, and transfer to four-year institutions for LIFG students in engineering.

Four types of interrelated activities are proposed for the LIFG engineering students and STEM faculty at Red Rocks Community College. First, faculty workshops, conferences, and discussions will be used to develop shared understandings of the challenges facing LIFG students. STEM faculty will serve as transforming agents by developing new pedagogies and meaningful mentorships that enrich teaching and learning in the STEM disciplines. Second, nontraditional mentoring strategies and a STEM 101 course will be developed to address how social and cultural capital contribute to self-efficacy and academic success for LIFG students. Students completing STEM 101 will participate in activities leading to authentic research opportunities in engineering at the Colorado School of Mines. These undergraduate research experiences will draw on and reinforce students' STEM knowledge and build expertise in engineering. Third, students will be provided with opportunities for experiential learning on engineering projects directly relevant to their lives and their communities. These will be based on an Introduction to Design and Engineering Applications (IDEA) program already developed by Red Rocks Community College in collaboration with the Colorado School of Mines and the Engineering by Doing (EbD) program developed by the Humanitarian Engineering program at the Colorado School of Mines. Fourth, the partnership between Red Rocks Community College and the Colorado School of Mines will be developed as a model for building community college-university collaborations that provide LIFG students with stronger academic preparation and more accessible pathways for transfer to 4-year institutions and for developing careers in engineering.

The project will investigate how these activities contribute to STEM learning and retention through a pre/post design that will compare a set of metrics that establish baseline measures of retention, success in gatekeeper courses, number of STEM students who reach second tier STEM courses, and success in these courses. Information also will be collected through student and faculty surveys, inventories, questionnaires, direct observations, and academic capstone assessments of integrated learning. The goals are to generate models and evidence on these approaches and provide materials that will be useful for other community colleges struggling to address the important issues of low enrollment, poor performance, weak retention, and lack of persistence among low-income and first-generation students in engineering and STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Improving the retention and success of low-income and first-generation (LIFG) students, overwhelmingly enrolled in community colleges, is critical for increasing the number of STEM graduates nationwide. Our project is developing new approaches and models to better engage and support low-income and/or first generation (LIFG) students in pre-engineering programs to improve success, retention, motivation, and persistence to transfer to four-year institutions in engineering.  Our goals were to:

  1. Develop faculty knowledge and pedagogy on how to engage LIFG students in the STEM classroom.
  2. Develop a meaningful mentoring process for LIFG students.
  3. Create a relevant learning environment through pedagogy that engages LIFG students.
  4. Motivate LIFG students to pursue a STEM pathway through real-world and research experiences.
  5. Provide a model of community college - university collaboration and transfer as a pathway for LIFG students to enter the engineering workforce.

Key results from the grant work included the following:

Faculty Development

  • With faculty from Colorado School of Mines, we developed an interactive workshop on increasing faculty understanding of issues surrounding LIFG success, especially key concepts identified in our literature review, such as belonging uncertainty, four capitals (social, cultural, knowledge, and financial) and their impact on student success, and a range of barriers to LIFG student success as well as ways to help such students overcome them.
  • Additional trainings for part-time science faculty were developed with two goals: 1) increasing understanding of barriers and opportunities for LIFG students, social and cultural capital and how that impacts LIFG students, and why mentoring is important for LIFG students, and 2) what is active learning, how it can be implemented in the STEM classroom, and how it engages LIFG students. This training is now part of RRCC?s professional development for part-time faculty to advance in the tiered pay system.

For slide decks and literature review from the workshops, please see rrcc.edu/stem/diversity

Engaging LIFG students

  • Developed a new project-based class that introduces engineering design through a hands-on, real world project. The course, Introduction to Design and Engineering Applications (IDEA) is now an approved transfer course for Colorado School of Mines and CU-Boulder. Launched in 2014, the IDEA class has enrolled 223 students, of whom 130 (58%) are LIFG students.  Over 8 semesters, 83 (64%) successfully transferred in STEM.
  • Created the IDEA Lab as an alternative learning environment where LIFG students engage in real world problem solving. Of the IDEA Lab participants enrolled 2017-2018, 58% are LIFG. We also found a 61% year-to-year retention rate for LIFG students compared to 39% for non-LIFG students. The IDEA Lab supported several teams to participate in the NSF Community College Innovation Challenge (CCIC). RRCC was selected RRCC as a top 10 team each year 2015-2018, winning first place in 2015 and second in 2017. Each team had high enrollment of LIFG students. To see more about the IDEA Lab as a student-centered learning environment, see rrccidea.com

Retention and transfer

  • Based on a mentoring model, revised Introduction to Engineering and inserted it as the initial course in a new Guided Pathway in Engineering. The Guided Pathway is articulated to transfer to Colorado School of Mines and University of Colorado-Boulder, providing LIFG students with a much-needed roadmap to transfer.
  • Developed STEM Scholars program to improve confidence in STEM by engaging 21 LIFG students in authentic research experiences in engineering labs at Colorado School of Mines, CU-Boulder or with faculty at RRCC. Of the 21, 17 successfully transferred, 2 entered the STEM workforce, and 2 are still enrolled at RRCC. As a result of this grant that demonstrated how important research experiences is for student engagement, RRCC has now institutionalized STEM Expo and undergraduate research as part of our science department.
